segments.text: Well, I was born in 1929 in Germany, to be specific, in Königsberg, which was in Eastern Prussia, which was home.
The parents, however, came from central and southern Germany.
My father had been teaching economics, and of course, by being in university, you change.

And during the period until the beginning of the war, World War II, he was on the assistant and associate professor level, so it was a well-to-do family, although the saying there was, being a professor, you either have a perambulator or you have a car, and so we had the perambulator.
But it was, as I said, quite well-to-do middle class.
When the war started, I was 10 years old, that was 1939,

And six years later, in early 45, I'm sorry, in early 45, 945, we just got away one or two days ahead of the Soviet army and got out over the Baltic and ended up in the mountains of southeastern most Bavaria, opposite corner, sort of, of the empire.
Well, after the war, I first worked for a year or so in a nursery, growing first cabbages and then later on advancing to fixing graves.
But a year later, when my father had come back from prison camp and things settled down a little, I went back to school and received my high school degree, sort of high school degree, in 1947.
in Europe, or most of Europe at least, central Europe at least, the high school degree corresponds to an education vaguely equivalent to a college sophomore year.
So I was a little farther advanced than a high school graduate here.
And I would also say that in those years
because of the war that one was a little more mature than an ordinary 18 years old would be today.
So the choice of what to do was not as bad or as unclear as it very often is nowadays.

I had wavered between, I wanted to go to college, to university, which in those years, or in that country, was not as open in those years as it is now, but perhaps 10% or so, or not even 10%, the year class went to the university.
At any rate, I wanted to proceed and had wavered for quite a while to go into economics because of my father's profession, and biology.
and the biology came about by the influence of a childhood friend, where the high school had really no influence at all, because it was entirely language-oriented.
So I decided to go into biology, and the professional goal was to become a high school teacher,
on the continent is a very prestigious job.
And as far as the training goes, the university career, one is being trained in the ordinary university department rather than as it is here put into a school of education.
And therefore after having ended I could easily switch into the scientific career, which would be very difficult here.

Because in those years the admissions were quite limited because many universities were being destroyed and of course all the people coming back from the war or those who did come back wanting to study.
Therefore, as I said, the admission was limited and I had to sort of shop around who would take me, apply as graduate students do it now, apply at five or six different universities.
And just to give you a feel, Göttingen, which was the top science university then, just laughed at me and said, well, it's your grades.
I had a D in Latin and a good C in Greek, I think an A in English, and Bs or so in the sciences and in German.
They just said no.
And Göttingen had five Nobel Prize laureates, so they sort of could afford to beat me.
I was accepted in Heidelberg and began then to study biology, which really meant to study botany as well as zoology, because that is just the way it's set up.
And as minors, I had chosen chemistry and geography.
The training was, again, in American standards, to be a little more... to explain a little more to the American listener how this...
what my training had been.
The training in biology was, or in sciences in general, was quite unquantitative in the physics, for example, which was introductory lecture for all scientists,

the calculus was barely touched upon, and in the introductory chemistry, again, introductory for chemists as well as for people like me, and in biology, mathematics was practically not being used, which resulted in a fairly unquantitative training, overall training of biologists, and I believe that has not changed very much, and that is one of my principal weaknesses in hindsight.

I studied biology, geography, and chemistry, and for a while was tempted to become a geographer because it just seemed very interesting, and I mentioned that because I still have geographical leanings.
But the field was so overrun that I thought, well, it wouldn't lead anywhere.
And, in effect, for these sort of fairly rational reasons, decided against it.
And also there was another...

more irrational reason was there was a Banzer or the same name geographer who had been a very nice party man and so whenever I went on excursions somebody politely asked are you perhaps related to Banzer or you are not related to Banzer I hope and so I thought no let's stick to biology now as I said it was 47 I think I said it was 1947
And most of the students were of advanced age by having just coming back from the war.
The universities opened in 46 or 47 only.
And very young students, me being 18, were admitted.
So the atmosphere was really dominated by the war generation.
And these people didn't fool around as normally one does in the universities in the first one or two years, but began to study right away.
And, of course, we were carried along.
This is important.
Again, I may interject that in the old days, and it persists until now, I guess, on the continent, there were very few examinations.
You entered, and it was only 10% of the year class, so if you entered, then usually you made it.
That means you entered, if you had an adequate high school certificate, you had a reasonable expectation to finish.
And in my case, for example, I entered in 47%.
and had received the PhD in 55, there was no examination in the entire period excepting a few lab tests in chemistry, none examination whatsoever, which of course made fooling around relatively easy.
But as I said, the atmosphere was not like that so that I was sort of automatically conditioned to study like the other people who knew exactly what they wanted and that they wanted to get out fast.

Now, that there are no examination may sound a little strange, but there was some, the teachers could assess the students, because a very important tool of education there is, after the first one or two years, is to take seminars and give speeches.
And these seminars mean that you disappear for a month or so in the library, not be seen.
Just drop all lectures and do your seminar, prepare your seminar, which means, of course, independent study.
And you stand and fall, really, on these seminars.
In these seminars, the PhD candidates are being picked.
In the others, I just go on for whatever.
Yeah, I guess that is all about the undergraduate years.

Yeah, there were, of course, money problems, no state support, and you had to have private support, but because the economy was pretty bad, fathers had died in the war or were unemployed, so many had to scrounge more than usually, and I, for example, had to work one summer in a mine, coal mine, just to make money, which didn't do any harm, but it was an interesting experience, obviously, to work at 2,000 feet below ground level.
All right, that is the undergraduate time.
Now, again, in Central Europe, I think it is quite common or almost expected from you that you change your university to just be exposed to different teachers.
And in my case, I left Heidelberg in 1949 and chose to go to Kiel.
The purpose of changing was
to beef up my zoology because I thought I had gotten a good background in botany and geography had dropped, chemistry was sort of taken care of, so what was left was zoology.
And there were only, in that time, only three universities which had worthwhile zoology.
Three out of, I don't remember, 17 or so.
And the two of the universities, well, one was Göttingen, which didn't like me anyway, and one was in southern Germany, and the other one, the third one, was Kiel.
I wanted to go back to northern Germany, so that is how I got to Kiel.
The timing, the choice of why in that semester was because
the university authorities thought of introducing intermediate examinations to weed out people.
And I thought it was so horrible in thought and infringement on everything academic freedom stood for that I thought they must get along without me.
And so I went to Kiel.
The first year there was largely to be devoted to invertebrates.
And again, that is a little different from here, the situation here.

in your major then you spent on the what is equivalent to the graduate level essentially all day six days a week in those years morning to night in the what you would call here the lab which is combined lab and the neuroscience and lecture and so on so the first year was to be devoted to invertebrates and the

shareholder the principal teacher was remana who's name i've written down who is known in this country as being the inventor of benthic male fauna work but who has done very much more than that he was in great morphologist and comparative anatomy new ecology natural history ecology sort of
and also was a very convincing teacher and human being, so that it was natural that you were carried along by him, and that it was natural that he determined the whole atmosphere in that place.

And it would have been natural, really, to continue with him, but after a week or two, one late afternoon, two of my colleagues in that lab got up early and went away looking at their watches, and I asked, well, where are you going?

And the answer was, well, we are going to a seminar in oceanography, in the Institute of Oceanography, or perhaps more properly called Institute of Oceanology, because it comprises all the branches of oceanography.
And I sort of, being tired of drawing, making drawings of cross-sectional, where it was, I said, well, all right, may I come along?
And they said, yes.

that is interesting what I'm telling now is that I really got by accident into oceanography because until that afternoon I had never realized that this was a discipline of its own in spite of the geography training but well the ocean just wasn't there sort of now what it was was where we went to was their first seminar the opening afternoon they had been
There had been an Institute of Oceanography before, before the war, but they had been bombed out and everybody was killed, man and mouse, as we say.
The library went up in flames.
And that semester, winter semester of 49 to 50, they had finally moved into permanent quarters, which was a converted large home, mansion-type home.
And so now I had the possibility to have a lecture hall and offer a seminar, and so that was the occasion.
So we went there and found five professors and, oh, I don't know, six, eight students sitting there, and then the three of us entering, so it was an unusual student-to-teacher ratio.
And in front at the podium was Professor Wüst, or Wüst, as we say in Germany, who was its shareholder.
which means the director of the institute and the one who had to stay.

There were four other professors whom we would call here associate professors, but who in that hierarchical structure never could be promoted to full professor because the budget for the institute had one full professor.
And as long as the full professor was there, the others were forced to remain associate professors, one for algae, one for zoology, and so on.

And Wüst, as I implied or said, conducted the seminar, which, and said by means of introduction that this was in part an exercise for students and in part for mutual education, it would be run like a sort of journal club.
And you, Ms. So-and-so, wouldn't you be interested in reviewing such and such?

and so on, and of course picked the people he knew who were sort of accepted PhD candidates among these six or eight first, and then in the end there was still a pile, a big pile of books on the, or articles on the table, and so wouldn't you, I don't know your name, addressing me, be interested in reviewing this book, and I can't really read it, he said,
But I have been assured it's interesting, and now what does a young student say?
Yes, sir.

And it turned out to be 200 pages in Swedish on the carbonate system in seawater, in the Baltic Sea, by Buch, who is an outstanding, one of the leading chemical oceanographers of those days, Buch in Finland.
And I had two months.

over the Christmas vacation two months' time to learn Swedish and learn the subject matter and then deliver, which I did, and fairly successfully, because from the sort of capital I had accumulated by that performance in front of all the professors, I lived then for the next two or three years.
But it was a little difficult, because the new subject and then the Swedish language, which turned out to be much more difficult than I had thought.
I thought it was difficult.
Oh, no.
No, no.
I have transcribers who will understand it.
Okay.
All right.
Well, and during these two months, I had to ask, of course, many questions and learn to meet these people.
And as I said, because of the favorable student-to-professor ratio, which was very unusual for those days in these crowded universities, I just met living professors.
and establish a personal relation to them, so that there was really a temptation right away to stay, especially with Kribe, who was the plantologist and also took care of the nutrient chemistry.
There was no chemist proper.
But then, on the other hand, Riemann had suggested already the subject for the PhD thesis to work on the head development of amphipodes.
and for a year I sort of vacillated, didn't quite know what to do.

Maintaining a seat in the zoology department, but already going out on cruises with these oceanographers and working upon urging by Krai on alkalinity, which was what his paper by Buch had been about, really.

But a year later then, yeah, and I'm sorry, and Krai, what Krai wanted to have done is really in continuation of the work of his teacher, Wattenberg, who had been the chemist that killed, who had been killed, however, during the war.
And Krai thought it was natural to continue.
After all, I had mastered the literature, and so why shouldn't I continue, and so on and so forth.
But a year later then, I decided, first of all, the geologist told me, now either you start

seat or just place and I said well alright I'm becoming oceanographer but I also decided then within oceanography that I could not possibly that it would be very unwise to work on this alkalinity business because then as a thesis I would have probably been good thesis subject but I would be labeled as a chemist and I didn't have the chemist training so I said to Kai that would

i would be happy to stay become your student but not with this subject which took him a while to understand but well what he then said is well uh i just received this book here which i have here which is by torson which came out in 46 and was the reproduction of

reproduction and larval development of danish marine bottom invertebrates which is a sort of bible for many of us in those years because it opened a new field the larval the pelagic larvae of bottom invertebrates as a part of the life history of benthic animals and
As you see, it's very thick, so it is in the Bible in the sense of that you should look very often in it, into it, and remind yourself of what's being said.
And Christ said, well, why not do the same in Kielbein?
And again, that had to do with earlier work by Wattenberg, his teacher whom I had mentioned.
who had already worked on the issue of the transport of marine animals from the North Sea through the Danish waters, Danish Straits, into the Baltic.
And the Baltic has very much lower salinity, so that many species don't intrude into the Baltic, but the keel bay is a sort of transition area.
And what Kai suggested, a little naively, but in a sense it was right, was to study the factors which limit or delimit a distribution of the species.
Now, I began to work on it through the literature.
I had to still to take courses and went in 1951 to 1952 to Sweden.
And that had several reasons.
One of it was that my father, who had to pay all these studies, said, well, I have now the money to allow you to go abroad, which is, of course, always a very good suggestion.
I had realized that the library, anywhere in Germany, the library facilities would be too poor because of the losses in the war to work through the literature which Thorsten had used.
So I tried to reread all the papers on larval development and sort them out in a different way.
because Thorson had dedicated this book to Johann Petersen, who is the inventor of quantitative benthic research and who had been his teacher in Denmark.
And Petersen had worked in the early part of the century.
And the dedication was more than a token because, as I implied earlier, the book was really written or was concerned with the pelagic larva as a stage in the life history of a bottom animal.
And my idea was to ask in the thesis, what can we learn by looking at the larvae as an pelagic animal?
Never mind that it has to land on the bottom, but what does it do while it is in the plankton?
That was the sort of core idea.
And so I wanted to read the literature he had reviewed once more to see whether he had not omitted certain things.
And of course, I wanted to
be up on the most recent literature, the last half decade after the war.
And so that is what I then connected with going to Sweden.
So I studied in Lund at the University of Lund in southern Sweden first.
Not really studied, but essentially worked at the library.
and during the summer of 52 then went to the Swedish Skagrak coast which has very much higher salinity than Kiel Bay to see the larvae actually.
Of course I had other ideas in my mind too but in hindsight this is what I learned to see the living animals before I started to study them in Kiel Bay.
The Thorson Bible is about all bottom invertebrates but
It seemed obvious that I couldn't treat all of them.

I had to specialize in one or two groups, two of them being very, very good and also having helpers, but I thought, well, and everybody advised, well, you can't work as comprehensively if you ever want to finish in a reasonable time.
And I had asked Thorsen, what would you suggest, which group should I pick?
And Thorsen had immediately said, well, obviously the mollusks and perhaps the bivalves, because they are least known, and there you easily can find new things.
But I thought, well, I'm not interested in describing new larvae, but I would like to know what larvae do, never mind what they belong to.

decided that I rather should settle on that group which is best known so that I do not have to worry about identification that I just identifying I would just go to the keys and begin counting in order to make statements about the ecology so I picked echinoderms on that account which at that time were the best known by about larvae with hard parts easy to identify and so on
But then I realized also that there are very few echinoderms living in the Bay of Keel because of the low salinity.
Most of them drop out earlier.
And so I had to pick another group.
And the choice was then polychaetes.
And that was sort of half rational, half irrational.
The rational part was, yes, I needed another group, reasonably well known.
And the sort of, not irrational is too much, but

The other part of my thinking was that the zoologist among these professors I had mentioned in the oceanography department, Friedrich, as we say, who later went to Bremerhaven and wrote a textbook there, many people still use, he was an ecologist and physiologist, but his taxonomic specialty had been polychaetes.

polychaetes are very important on the seabed, half of the species also are polychaetes, and I thought, well, if Friedrich leaves, well, somebody has to identify polychaetes, and so I chose polychaetes.
And that sounds now a little more cunning than I actually was, but I thought it was an empty niche, and why shouldn't I occupy it, sort of?
And that is then what I studied on the Swedish Skagrak coast, and in the library, the echinoderm and polychaete larvae.

And while in Lund, thinking about it, how to do it, what to do, when coming back, what courses to make, the sort of revelation, if I may put it this way, it really came one night, laying in bed, out of the blue, how to sample was to forget about the nets, as all people had worked before on plankton, with nets, but to use a plankton pump.

That is the key of the success, that I settled on a tool which allows you to lower the hose into one spot at depth and take out so much water as you need, which means that, in contrast to a net which you tow over a certain distance and you never quite know where you were and what the salinity was and so on.
So the fact that I showed the sampling tool, which not only

where I was not only sure how much water was sampled, but I also was sure where the sample had been taken from, which allowed me also to take phytoplankton samples and salinity samples and, in other words, to describe the environment.
That, in hindsight, turned out to be the key to the success.
I did all the collection in 1953.
And during that time, I increased the number of stations ever worked on with the pump by an order of magnitude.
There had been four stations by Torsen and two or three elsewhere, but I had 10 times as many, which of course helped.
and defended the thesis in 1955.
Let me just say one more thing about the pump series by Thorsen.

Thorsen had used a pump, a hand-driven pump, as you use in a farmer's yard, which is in a very laborious way, three or four times during his studies, and had given the original data, and while looking at the data, I thought that the interpretation he gave to that must- can't possibly be right.
And
In a way, the thesis starts out from, or the whole approach started out from looking at these curves and saying Torsten's interpretation can't be right.

And in a way, also later, I have, many of my papers are really built on mistakes by others that I, rather than starting out from scratch, that I just read the literature and thought, well, that doesn't sound right.

doesn't hold water and shouldn't I check it and well as I said many of my papers are based on the mistakes of others which however I think many other people do few have an idea completely out of the blue but they start out from somewhere and well I started out from the mistakes of others so that was then the thesis where I counted about 1,000 samples or so just to give you a feel for
the magnitude of the effort.
It really was sitting on the microscope and not worrying about girls or things, but really work.
But concurrently still thinking of, or really being urged by cry,

All right, go for the PhD, but I don't know of any position, so don't gamble on now that you will become an oceanographer, but continue with your teacher's training, take that botany course, which was utterly boring, and do this and do that in order to have all right the PhD, but have a living income by becoming a high school teacher.
Because at that time,
the German education, the German universities were still sort of limping along because there was not just enough money around.
And before the war, they had been the same way, and Christ sort of remembered that, how difficult it was to make a living as a scientist.
And it was reasonable to suggest, well, play it safe.

In addition to this counting and then this going to boring courses, I wrote already some papers on larvae development of polychaetes because I did run into new larvae and it was obvious to describe this separately rather than put them into the big thesis.
And of course also by necessity I became acquainted with the taxonomy of the adults so that I could identify polychaetes.
And this is an important point which will come up later.
